text:
Hi guys. I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I want to show you

how to make a Sicilian pizza. Now I am not
saying that this is the kind of pizza you

get in Sicily, I'm just telling you that - you
know - in the U.S when you order Sicilian

pizza you get the thick crust, square pan
pizza and that is what I am going to show

you today. I'm going to take you step by step
starting with some pizza dough. Now you can

make your own fresh pizza dough or you can
buy it at your local grocery store or pizza

place. Now what I have here - first of all
what I have here is a Sicilian pizza pan,

this is a really nice heavy duty pizza pan
that's got high sides and I have a little

bit of vegetable oil that I have brushed all
on the inside and up the sides of the pizza

pan. Now you're going to need two balls of
dough, both of these are about a pound each.

You're going to take each one and you're going
to stack it - you're going to shake off all

the excess flour and you're going to stack
the two on top of each other. Now I know this

looks crazy but that's just what you need
to do. Now what you do is that you kind of

push the two together and you stretch this
out to fit the inside of your pizza pan. Now

you can do one of two things; you can roll
this out ahead of time, you know, on your

cutting board or your work surface with just
a rolling pin or you can do what I do and

just take your time and press it evenly in
your baking pan. Now you can see I'm kind

of picking it up and stretching it out and
flipping it over, because that is just what

you have to do, you have to keep things moving
and just stretch this out to fill your baking

pan or your pizza pan I should say. That looks
good enough for me, I'm not going to worry

about it not going into the corners perfectly
because this now has to rest. Now what I am

going to do is I am going to cover this with
some plastic wrap and I just - I don't wrap

it around like I would wrap - on a bowl. I
just take some plastic wrap and you just want

to make sure that it is tucked in, like so.
I am not going to wrap around the baking sheet,

I am going to place this somewhere to rest
and rise for a good while till it is about

one and a half times the size, and it is - not
doubled but a little bit bigger than it is

now and then we will get going on the next
step. My pizza dough has been resting for

about a half hour, you can see that it has
risen quite a bit. Now I just go in with my

fingers and continue to kind of stretch it
out - flatten it a bit if you need to, just

kind of work it with your hands. A great thing
about Sicilian pizza is that you make it in

a pan, you don't have to worry about having
it perfectly thin or whatever because it just

works really - really its just - it's foolproof.
You just press it into a pan and you're good

to go. Again, don't worry if the corners don't
catch because that's perfectly fine. So now

you want to make sure that your oven is preheated
to 450F. I have my pizza here - what I have

here is some pizza sauce. This is my no cook
pizza sauce, I have this recipe linked up

with my original pizza video, so if you'll
go to www.Laurainthekitchen.com just go to

my original pizza recipe video the no cook
pizza sauce will be listed there, but you

can use your favorite pizza sauce, marinara
sauce, whatever you have left over. Now what

we are going to do is - this is going to be
so good my mouth is salivating already. I

am going to take some of this, not all of
it and I am going to smear a thin layer of

this evenly all over the top. That looks awesome.
Now I am going to pop this into my oven that's

been preheated to 450F for 10 minutes. After
10 minutes I will show you the next step.

My pizza was in the oven for exactly 10 minutes,
now I am spreading on the rest of my sauce

- get it all off there or I should say get
it all out of there. Then I am just going

to use a spoon to make my life a little bit
easier. See how it is really nice and thick?

That is what I like. I love Sicilian pizza.
I am a huge, I am talking huge fan of - that

is a timer - of anything pepperoni, pepperoni
pizza is my favorite, it's just what I dig,

so today I am going to do half pepperoni and
half plain because that is just the way I

roll. I am just going to take some shredded
mozzarella - now you guys know I use to work

in my dad's pizza shop for years so I am quite
use to making pizza, I like to think that

I am pretty good at it. I know a thing or
two about a thing or two when it comes to

pizza making. You can make definitely a thicker
amount of cheese, a thicker layer I should

say, but that is enough for me. I am just
going to take some pepperoni, this is just

some sliced pepperoni and I am going to do
half pepperoni and keep the other half plain

because we like options around here. I like
to sprinkle a little bit of oregano on top.

Now this is going to go back in the oven for
another 15 minutes or so or until the cheese

is ooey-gooey melted, the pizza crust should
be golden brown and crispy. We will let it

cool for just a few minutes and then dig in.
In she goes! My pizza went back in for 15

minutes, I let it cool for a couple minutes
but I wanted you to see the bottom a little

bit, how it's beautiful crusty golden brown.
That my friend is exactly what you're looking

for and I am just dying to dig in. I'm just
going to take my big pizza cutter, and I have

showed you this tip before where you kind
of rock it back and fourth so it doesn't disturb

your pieces, your toppings I should say. I
am just going to cut them into squares, some

are going to be bigger than others but to
be honest I am trying to do this fast because

I cannot wait another second to eat this and
those of you who really know me know that

I just obsess over anything pepperoni, it's
just my thing and the corner slice of a pepperoni

pizza has my name written all over it every
single time. I am going to go for this one

right here. Look at that crust - perfect crust,
the cheese is phenomenal. It just looks so

good! This is going to be really hot though
so give a girl a minute here. Clearly I'm

obsessed because I took two bites of it when
the camera was off and I apologize, but it

was one of those things where I went into
a daze and then all of a sudden Joe is like

we need to finish this and I said they will
forgive me. They know I am greedy with food

and have no patience. But this is just so
phenomenal and by all means do whatever you

want with the toppings. If you don't want
pepperoni then don't put pepperoni. If you

don't want all cheese - if you don't want
as much cheese, use less cheese. You can do

whatever your heart desires. I, like I said,
I have to do pepperoni when it comes to Sicilian

pizza and a corner slice. It is just my thing.
www.laurainthekitchen.com will have the recipe

ready for you, I hope you enjoyed spending
time with me. I will see you next time. Bye-bye.
